The worst-case scenario is defined as a catastrophic failure of the largest volume containing piece of equipment in the covered process.  The alternative release scenario is an event that is more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario and will reach an endpoint offsite, unless no such scenario exists.   
With the exception of one event in December of 2003, there have been no accidental releases of ammonia at the facility in the last 5 years.  The ammonia leak in question resulted in the release of approximately 20-50 lbs. of anhydrous ammonia and lubricant oil from the low temperature (LT) chiller.  The release was the result of a broken ferrule on a piece of stainless steel tubing.  The ammonia release was detected by an Operations and Maintenance (O&M) Technician and the fire department was summoned.  The Ripon Fire Department was able to contain and stop the leak without any effects to the surrounding area.  No injuries to site personnel resulted from the leak.  The San Joaquin County Office of Emergency Services (OES) representative reviewed the containment procedure and the implemented cleanup measures, and indicated their satisfaction with the response.  As a result of the leak, the tubing was added to the maintenance program and is now regularly inspected during maintenance intervals and monitored for potential wear.
RC has developed a written emergency response plan and procedures to minimize the effects of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia on employees, the public, and the environment.  The Ripon Fire Department is considered the first responder for accidental releases.  RC has developed appropriate emergency response procedures and plans pursuant to the General Duty clause of the 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 68 requirements.  The Ripon Cogeneration facility is not itself considered a first responder at the present time, so RC personnel will perform ?awarenes

s level? duties only, which simply means that once an ammonia emergency is discovered, RC personnel will make the proper notification to set the emergency procedure in motion.  The Emergency Response Plan procedures are reviewed at least annually to ensure that they remain accurate and current.  Employees are trained on the procedure when initially hired, when the procedures are revised, and when employees? responsibilities are changed.  All employees receive annual refresher training on the emergency response program.
As part of the RMP update the process hazard analysis (PHA) was updated.  The most significant aspect of this exercise was that the cooling system, previously omitted from the PHA, was added.  The inlet air cooling system presented additional anhydrous ammonia release scenarios at the Ripon facility which had not been previously identified and analyzed.  However, none of these scenarios were deemed to be more likely than the ARS selected in the 2002 PHA.  No changes were made to the ammonia systems as a result of the PHA update.
